page.title: 12INDUSTRY
page.content: The various cement works and ancillary buildings were built after the first world war. What follows are the recollections of an electrical engineer who served his apprenticeship at the Cement Works from 1944 until August 1949. "I went there when I was fifteen and a half but had to wait until I was sixteen to become an apprentice. I was paid six shilling a week for the first year. We started work at seven o'clock in the morning until five o'clock. On Saturdays we had to work from 7 till 12 noon. In those days, before I had a motor bike I used to catch the train from Barry Station at 6.25 a.m. Of course the line is now only used for goods trains and emergencies. I had to do general maintenance work, on switchgear, wiring and motors."
